attributes.title: Effects of minimal group assignments on resource allocation

summary.value:
This is an amendment to the preregistration submitted on 03/22/2020. We created four versions of Qualtrics survey to counterbalance the position of each group in the Tajfel matrices. 

For example, in one version, the top row always represents the points for the overestimator and the bottom row always represents the points for the underestimator. In another script their positions switch (underestimator top row and overestimator bottom row). We did this for the Klee and Kandinsky version of our research as well. Please see the four Qualtrics scripts uploaded for these changes. 

Overestimator-top & underestimator-bottom (Tajfel_Matricies_NEST1.qsf)
Understimator-top & overestimator-bottom (Tajfel_Matricies_NEST2.qsf)

Kandinsky-top & Klee-bottom (Tajfel_Matricies_ART1.qsf)
Klee-top & Kandinsky-bottom (Tajfel_Matricies_ART2.qsf)


We have not started data collection for this project yet and we will not begin data collection until after this preregistration amendment has been submitted.

attributes.title: What are the Relationships between Impulsivity, Scarcity and Addiction?
attributes.description: A survey of trait and behavioural measures of impulsivity and actual and perceived social status during adulthood and childhood.

q1.value: Addiction: What is the Relationship between childhood scarcity and adult impulsivity?

q3.value:
We know that early experiences of deprivation can have serious consequences for an individuals’ neurobiological, social, behavioural, and cognitive development (Rutter, 1972). Adults who experience severe and prolonged deprivation as a child are more likely to be diagnosed with a wide range of psychiatric, cognitive, and social impairments (Sonuga-Barke et. al., 2017). What is less known is how scarcity, as opposed to deprivation, influences the development of individual differences in behaviour and cognition. Evidence suggests that people from less affluent environments tend to make poorer life choices and decisions than individuals from wealthier backgrounds. Rates of smoking, alcohol consumption, obesity, debt dependence and symptoms of psychiatric disorders associated with impulse control are not uniformly distributed across the social strata.

Aims:
This study aims to replicate the findings of Griskevicius et. al. (2013), who reported that adult participants who experienced economic uncertainty during their childhood showed greater delay-reward discounting after viewing images of recession. 
The study also aims to investigate the processes that lead to trait impulsivity in adults, specifically testing whether economic scarcity during childhood affects adult choice behaviour, and the relationship between impulsivity, scarcity and addiction.
 
Research Setting:
Participants will be invited to take part in an online survey advertised by Prolific (https://prolific.ac) and hosted on Qualtrics (https://qualitrics.com). The survey will be investigating the relationships between actual and perceived socio-economic statuses, psychometric and behavioural measures of impulsivity, coping motives, personality dimensions and addiction.

Method:
Participants will be asked to complete a series of short standardised questionnaires, first indicating their age, height, weight and gender. Participants will complete the National Statistics Social Economic Status (NS-SEC) and the MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status twice, once to indicate their current economic status and once to indicate their childhood economic status. Following this they will complete a number of reports on impulsivity and addiction, a measure of motivations for gambling, a measure of personality dimensions and a psychometric measure of impulsivity.
1. Age
2. Gender
3. Height
4. Weight
5. National Statistics Social Economic Status – current (NSSEC: Chandola et. al., 2000)
6. MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status - current (SSS: Adler and Stewart 2007)
7. National Statistics Social Economic Status – childhood (NSSEC: Chandola et. al., 2000)
8. MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status - childhood (SSS: Adler and Stewart 2007)
9. Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT: Babor et al, 2001)
10. Cigarette Dependence Scale (CDS-5: Etter et al, 2003)
11. Drugs Use Disorders Identification test (DUDIT: Berman et al, 2002)
12. Problem Gambling Severity Index (PGSI: Ferris and Wynne, 2001)
13. DSM-V Recommended Criteria for Gaming Disorder (DSM-V: American Psychiatric Association)
14. Three-factor Eating Questionnaire (TFE-Q: Karlsson et al, 2000)
15. Debt Questions (Indicate from a list of bills which payments the individual has ever missed)
16. Gambling Motives Questionnaire – Financial (GMQ-F: Schellenberg, 2014)
17. Substance Use Risk Profile Scale (SURPS: Woicik et al, 2009)
18. Barratt Impulsiveness Scale-11 (BIS-11: Patton et al., 1995)

q4.value:
1. Scarcity during childhood leads to higher impulsivity as an adult. 

2. Impulsivity is not normally distributed across different socioeconomic groups.

question.value: We will be measuring participants actual socioeconomic status using the NS-SEC and their perceived socioeconomic status using the MacArthur Scale of Subjective Social Status and also the questions posed by Griskevicius et al (2013). We will ask participants to answers these questionnaires twice, considering their current situation and then their childhood. We will also measure participants impulsive behaviour related to alcohol (AUDIT), substances (DUDIT and CDS-5), gambling (PGSI), spending (Debt Questions), gaming (DSM-5 Criteria for Gaming Disorder), and eating (TFEQ-18). Finally we will measure gambling motives (GMQ-F), impulsivity (BIS-11 and Kirby Delay Discounting), and substance use risk factors (SURPS).

attributes.title: Transition to Parenthood and Therapy Willingness

q1.value: Transition to Parenthood and Attitudes towards Therapy

q3.value:
This study will research how transition to parenthood affects attitudes towards therapy seeking. Much research has been done studying the effects of transition to parenthood (Parfitt & Ayers, 2014; Murray, Cooper, & Hipwell, 2003), and much has been inquired in the realm of attitudes towards therapy (ethnicity article, opinions about mental illness, emotional openness,). Although there has yet been an inquisition into how entering parenthood can affect parent’s attitudes towards enrolling in psychological therapy. 
Entering parenthood is seen as a developmental stage in life (Parens, 1975) that has many consequences on the parents. It entails changes in the everyday reality for example in expenses, couple relationships, and relationships with the couples parents. Parenthood brings changes in the inner reality as well such as change in values (Lönnqvist, Leikas, & Verkasalo, 2018), attitudes and beliefs (Palkovitz & Copes, 1988) . Parenting induces positive and negative changes (UMBERSON & GOVE, 1989). Most research has focused on the negative aspects of the transition, focusing on the stress that aroused due to the new stage in life and on the risk of postpartum depression (Parfitt & Ayers, 2014) (Murray, Cooper, & Hipwell, 2003). However, some researchers ‘defend’ parenthood, highlighting positive aspects that arrive with parenting (Nelson, Kushlev, English, Dunn, & Lyubomirsky, 2013). In their study, they found parenting to increase frequency of thoughts about meaning in parents, and an increase in presence of meaning (POM) for fathers. They believed mothers have increased POM due to parenting that is offset by increased stress. Supporting that is their finding that stress and presence of meaningare inversley related. In a study by Steger and others (2009) depression was found to be negatively correlated with POM (r = -0.60). This study will examine ways in which stress and newfound meaning effect attitudes and intentions to seek therapy, while pinpointing the way mothers are effected. Previous research (Bina & Glasser, 2019) found postpartum depression to be a significant factor affecting attitudes to seek therapy. 
In their new role as parents, therapy and guidance can be of use, and as Bryan (2000) noted that ‘‘During times of transition, preventive intervention may be especially useful’’ (p. 143). Surprisingly enough, therapy is underutilised (Mackenzie, Gekoski, & Knox, 2006), even when it is economically accessible. The purpose of the study is to see how positive and negative aspects of entering parenthood affects attitudes towards therapy seeking. 

1.	How does transition to parenthood affect attitudes towards seeking help for mothers?
2.	Does presence of meaning moderate stress levels?
3.	Does anticipated regret affect attitudes towards seeking psychological help? (exploratory)
4.	Does Postpartum anxiety (PPA) affect therapy attitudes differently than PPD? Such that anxiety evokes positive attitudes and depression negative (exploratory). 
5.	Will an additional POM raise intentions to seek therapy?

q4.value: We predict that transition to parenthood will increase positive attitudes towards therapy seeking (h1). Specifically, that the increased stress and POM will lead to a more favorable attitude towards therapy (h2,h3). In addition, we believe that presence of meaning will moderate the stress levels, so that mothers with higher POM will be less effected by stress symptoms in their attitudes towards therapy (h4).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: mixed design, two group (pregnant,non-pregnant), repeated measures (third trimester, 3 months postpartum; 4-6 months between measures). The aim will be to have a more or less matching between populations sociodemographically, but no pairing will be used between groups.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value:
100-120 Pregnant and 100-120 non-pregnant non-mothers female particpants will be recruited from online forums and social media in Israel, starting from April 1 2020, and until reaching the required amount. Women will be eligible to participate if they are above 18 years of age, Jewish, and in the third trimester of their pregnancy, and signed a consent form. The participating woman will be asked to participate in a follow up survey, 3 months postpartum. 
Woman screened positive for post partum depression (PPD) (EPDS >= 9) will be informed that they have PPD symptoms, and might have PPD. They will receive a short explanation about PPD, numerous viable treatmants, and recieve a referral. Referrals will be made to numerous facilities offering a few treatment and payment options. 
The study was submitted to the college and the health center’s Helsinki committe and received approval #2020061 on Mar 17, 2020. At the third trimester of their pregnancy, particapating peripartum women will sign an informed consent form and given the first survey, which will contain a demographic questionnaire, the Attitudes Toward Seeking Professional Psychological Help Scale – Short Form (Fischer, et al., 1970), the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS; (Cox, Holden, & Sagovsky, 1987), ISCI (Cash et al., 1975)  and the Meaning in Life Questionnaire (Steger, Frazier, Oishi, & Kaler, 2006).

question.value: All participants will be surveyed by filling in an online survey and contacted by telephone (call or text) or via e-mail for a follow up survey. They will be asked to fill in an online form similar to the one they filled out. In addition they will be asked about the mental health of the infant and his temprament and whether they would feel regret if they did not go to therapy. Women will be surveyed in Hebrew. A prize of 200NIS will be raffled to one of the participants.

q13.value: The original plan was to collect 80 women on two separate occasions. Expecting between 66%-80% to fill in the follow up survey, any number between 100-120 women will be asked to partake in the survey. Due to Coronavirus effecting participants responses, it was decided that a control group will be recruited.

q14.value: Due to the original plan requiring four regressions, 20 participants were needed for each test, amounting to 80 participants. Another 80 were added for a control group.

q15.value: Once reaching 80-82 participants that filled in each of the conditions.

question.value:
ATSPPH-SF – Hebrew Version
This scale comprises 10 items regarding respondents’ level of agreement on a 4-point Likert scale (ranging from 0 to 3). Scores are summed for a total ranging from 0 to 30, with higher scores indicating more positive attitudes toward seeking MHT if needed.
EPDS – Hebrew Version
The EPDS is a self-report scale consisting of 10 short statements of common depressive and anxious symptoms (Cox, Holden, & Sagovsky, 1987). Women chose the responses that best described the way they had been feeling during the past seven days. There are four possible responses on a Likert scale ranging from low severity (0 = normal response) of the symptom to high severity (3 = severe response) of the symptom. 
(Exploratory)The EPDS can be divided to depression and anxiety subscales (Bina and Harrington 2016). The depression subscale (EPDS-D), includes six items (1, 2, 7, 8, 9 and 10), and the anxiety subscale (EPDS-A) includes three items (3, 4, and 5). Scores for the items on each subscale are summed, resulting in a possible score of 0–18 on the depression subscale and 0–9 on the anxiety subscale, with higher scores reflecting greater symptom severity.
MLQ – Hebrew Version
The original MLQ questionnaire (Steger, 2006) consists of two subscales: presence of meaning in life (POM) and search for meaning in life (SFM). Items will be rated from 1 (absolutely untrue) to 7 (absolutely true) on a Likert scale; in the POM subscale there is one reverse-scored item and scores in each subscale range from 5 to 35. Higher scores reflect higher presence of meaning or increased search for meaning. This study will use the Hebrew version of MLQ (Littman-Ovadia & Steger, 2010).
Presence subscale score = inverse score #9, items 1, 4, 5, and 6. 
Search subscale score = items 2, 3, 7, 8, and 10. 
ISCI – Hebrew Version
The ISCI (Cash et al., 1975) is a help-seeking intention scale, in which respondents assess how likely they were to seek professional assistance for each of the 10 problems, on a 6-point Likert scale. Scores on all statements are summed, resulting in a score between 10-60, with higher scores indicating a larger likelihood to seek counseling for psychological and interpersonal concerns.

The original statistical plan included running four multiple regressions for each of the T2 measures. In the regression of attitudes (ATTHSPS-SF) and intentions towrads therapy (ISCI), POM will be measured as moderating stress levels effect on the dependant measure.

q20.value: Categorical variables will be coded as described above.

q21.value: 0.95 p-values. Two tailed tests will be used. The required amount of participants will be recruited in order to test the multiple hypotheses.

q22.value: If more than 20% of the data is missing, or participant answered insincerely (i.e. answered to all questions the same answer).

q23.value: The online form requires participants to answer all questions. If there is incomplete or missing data, the protocol required by each questionnaire used. If no protocol exists, the average score of existing data will be used instead of missing data.

registration_responses.q1: Transition to Parenthood and Attitudes towards Therapy
registration_responses.q3:
This study will research how transition to parenthood affects attitudes towards therapy seeking. Much research has been done studying the effects of transition to parenthood (Parfitt & Ayers, 2014; Murray, Cooper, & Hipwell, 2003), and much has been inquired in the realm of attitudes towards therapy (ethnicity article, opinions about mental illness, emotional openness,). Although there has yet been an inquisition into how entering parenthood can affect parent’s attitudes towards enrolling in psychological therapy. 
Entering parenthood is seen as a developmental stage in life (Parens, 1975) that has many consequences on the parents. It entails changes in the everyday reality for example in expenses, couple relationships, and relationships with the couples parents. Parenthood brings changes in the inner reality as well such as change in values (Lönnqvist, Leikas, & Verkasalo, 2018), attitudes and beliefs (Palkovitz & Copes, 1988) . Parenting induces positive and negative changes (UMBERSON & GOVE, 1989). Most research has focused on the negative aspects of the transition, focusing on the stress that aroused due to the new stage in life and on the risk of postpartum depression (Parfitt & Ayers, 2014) (Murray, Cooper, & Hipwell, 2003). However, some researchers ‘defend’ parenthood, highlighting positive aspects that arrive with parenting (Nelson, Kushlev, English, Dunn, & Lyubomirsky, 2013). In their study, they found parenting to increase frequency of thoughts about meaning in parents, and an increase in presence of meaning (POM) for fathers. They believed mothers have increased POM due to parenting that is offset by increased stress. Supporting that is their finding that stress and presence of meaningare inversley related. In a study by Steger and others (2009) depression was found to be negatively correlated with POM (r = -0.60). This study will examine ways in which stress and newfound meaning effect attitudes and intentions to seek therapy, while pinpointing the way mothers are effected. Previous research (Bina & Glasser, 2019) found postpartum depression to be a significant factor affecting attitudes to seek therapy. 
In their new role as parents, therapy and guidance can be of use, and as Bryan (2000) noted that ‘‘During times of transition, preventive intervention may be especially useful’’ (p. 143). Surprisingly enough, therapy is underutilised (Mackenzie, Gekoski, & Knox, 2006), even when it is economically accessible. The purpose of the study is to see how positive and negative aspects of entering parenthood affects attitudes towards therapy seeking. 

1.	How does transition to parenthood affect attitudes towards seeking help for mothers?
2.	Does presence of meaning moderate stress levels?
3.	Does anticipated regret affect attitudes towards seeking psychological help? (exploratory)
4.	Does Postpartum anxiety (PPA) affect therapy attitudes differently than PPD? Such that anxiety evokes positive attitudes and depression negative (exploratory). 
5.	Will an additional POM raise intentions to seek therapy?
registration_responses.q4: We predict that transition to parenthood will increase positive attitudes towards therapy seeking (h1). Specifically, that the increased stress and POM will lead to a more favorable attitude towards therapy (h2,h3). In addition, we believe that presence of meaning will moderate the stress levels, so that mothers with higher POM will be less effected by stress symptoms in their attitudes towards therapy (h4).

registration_responses.q11:
100-120 Pregnant and 100-120 non-pregnant non-mothers female particpants will be recruited from online forums and social media in Israel, starting from April 1 2020, and until reaching the required amount. Women will be eligible to participate if they are above 18 years of age, Jewish, and in the third trimester of their pregnancy, and signed a consent form. The participating woman will be asked to participate in a follow up survey, 3 months postpartum. 
Woman screened positive for post partum depression (PPD) (EPDS >= 9) will be informed that they have PPD symptoms, and might have PPD. They will receive a short explanation about PPD, numerous viable treatmants, and recieve a referral. Referrals will be made to numerous facilities offering a few treatment and payment options. 
The study was submitted to the college and the health center’s Helsinki committe and received approval #2020061 on Mar 17, 2020. At the third trimester of their pregnancy, particapating peripartum women will sign an informed consent form and given the first survey, which will contain a demographic questionnaire, the Attitudes Toward Seeking Professional Psychological Help Scale – Short Form (Fischer, et al., 1970), the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS; (Cox, Holden, & Sagovsky, 1987), ISCI (Cash et al., 1975)  and the Meaning in Life Questionnaire (Steger, Frazier, Oishi, & Kaler, 2006).

registration_responses.q17.question:
ATSPPH-SF – Hebrew Version
This scale comprises 10 items regarding respondents’ level of agreement on a 4-point Likert scale (ranging from 0 to 3). Scores are summed for a total ranging from 0 to 30, with higher scores indicating more positive attitudes toward seeking MHT if needed.
EPDS – Hebrew Version
The EPDS is a self-report scale consisting of 10 short statements of common depressive and anxious symptoms (Cox, Holden, & Sagovsky, 1987). Women chose the responses that best described the way they had been feeling during the past seven days. There are four possible responses on a Likert scale ranging from low severity (0 = normal response) of the symptom to high severity (3 = severe response) of the symptom. 
(Exploratory)The EPDS can be divided to depression and anxiety subscales (Bina and Harrington 2016). The depression subscale (EPDS-D), includes six items (1, 2, 7, 8, 9 and 10), and the anxiety subscale (EPDS-A) includes three items (3, 4, and 5). Scores for the items on each subscale are summed, resulting in a possible score of 0–18 on the depression subscale and 0–9 on the anxiety subscale, with higher scores reflecting greater symptom severity.
MLQ – Hebrew Version
The original MLQ questionnaire (Steger, 2006) consists of two subscales: presence of meaning in life (POM) and search for meaning in life (SFM). Items will be rated from 1 (absolutely untrue) to 7 (absolutely true) on a Likert scale; in the POM subscale there is one reverse-scored item and scores in each subscale range from 5 to 35. Higher scores reflect higher presence of meaning or increased search for meaning. This study will use the Hebrew version of MLQ (Littman-Ovadia & Steger, 2010).
Presence subscale score = inverse score #9, items 1, 4, 5, and 6. 
Search subscale score = items 2, 3, 7, 8, and 10. 
ISCI – Hebrew Version
The ISCI (Cash et al., 1975) is a help-seeking intention scale, in which respondents assess how likely they were to seek professional assistance for each of the 10 problems, on a 6-point Likert scale. Scores on all statements are summed, resulting in a score between 10-60, with higher scores indicating a larger likelihood to seek counseling for psychological and interpersonal concerns.
registration_responses.q19.question: The original statistical plan included running four multiple regressions for each of the T2 measures. In the regression of attitudes (ATTHSPS-SF) and intentions towrads therapy (ISCI), POM will be measured as moderating stress levels effect on the dependant measure.

attributes.title: Systematic review on the concepts of Social Determinants of Health and Social Determinants of Mental health: matryoshka or two independent constructs?
attributes.description: A systematic review of the literature on the constructs of Social Determinants of Health (SDH) and Social Determinants of Mental Health (SDMH), with a particular focus on what determinants have been identified, outcomes/dependent variables, and theoretical embeddings. The relevance of so-called “Social Determinants” for physical health has received much attention in the literature and the theoretical conceptualisation seems developed enough for the generation of assessment methods. The concept of SDMH on the other hand was developed more recently and, as such, is less well established. There are far fewer publications on SDMH and no methods for assessing these. Both concepts are not clearly related to each other. In consequence, it remains unclear whether SDMH is a subcategory of SDH or a separate concept. The current systematic review will address this question. First, both concepts will be examined within the literature, regarding their epistemological assumptions, their actual determinants and the treatment- and tackle-approaches they provide. Second, both concepts will be compared on the bases of the so extracted definitions.

q1.value: Fritz Handerer, Dr Sara Tai, Prof Peter Kinderman

q2.value: Research question: How are the Social Determinants of Health and the Social Determinants of Mental Health conceptualised? How do they compare to each other?

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The literature on SDH is immense and thus, for the purposes of review, it is necessary to restrict our search of the literature to a specific subsection. We will focus specifically on the literature related to the development of assessment methods for SDH, including literature dealing with the general task of assessing SDH. Any assessment must be a definition of the object of interest, in this case SDH, and thus offer a direct way into theoretical assumptions. This way is barraged regarding the SDMH because of the lack of an assessment method. Therefore, the review of SDMH-literature will focus on theoretical texts, describing the epistemological concept. These groundworks present the fundaments of assessment-method-development and the means of (construct-) validity checks. A scoping review revealed that the SDMH-literature in this area consists of an appropriate amount of texts. Both literature bodies will be reviewed separately and compared afterwards.

attributes.title: EFFECTS OF OURRELATIONSHIP AND EPREP ON INDIVIDUAL MENTAL AND PHYSICAL HEALTH FOR LOW INCOME COUPLES

q1.value: EFFECTS OF OURRELATIONSHIP AND EPREP ON INDIVIDUAL MENTAL AND PHYSICAL HEALTH FOR LOW INCOME COUPLES

q3.value:
1. Do online self-help relationship programs improve individual mental and physical health over the course of the program (2 months)?
2. Do online self-help relationship programs maintain improvements in individual mental health and improve individual physical health over short-term follow up (4 months)? 
3. Do initial levels of individual health moderate changes in individual mental health over the program and short term follow up as well as moderate changes in individual physical health over short term follow up? 
4. Are changes in individual physical health mediated through increases in intimacy, decreases in communication conflict, or decreases in psychological distress?

q4.value:
1. Individual mental health will improve over the course of the program. Individual physical health will not change over the course of the program. 
2. Individual metal health will maintain improvements seen during the program over short term follow up. Individual physical health will improve over short term follow up. 
3. Initial levels of individual health will moderate change in individual mental health over the program and in individual physical health over short term follow up. 
4. Decreases in relationship conflict and increases in relationship intimacy will mediate changes in individual physical health over the program.

q5.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q6.value: Data is collected as a part of an online program within the program software and through Qualtrics. All data is stored on Qualtrics servers and has been checked for completeness but not for content.

question.value:
Data Collection Procedures. Participants enter all data online via Qualtrics. If a participant does not complete an assessment, we ask them to complete a brief, 10-question assessment (over the phone or online) for a $5 payment. Implementation data is collected by the intervention coaches and the Participant Coordinator.
Collection of participants’ responses to surveys. Participants are required to complete both the intake for eligibility screening purposes and pre-test questions online before enrolling in services.  Completion is tracked by the Participant Coordinator, who daily monitors completion of both surveys as a prerequisite to enrollment; therefore, there will be no missing data on these measures. 
Collection of the required measures is carefully monitored by project staff to ensure completion. The Participant Coordinator, the work-study student working with him/her, or the assigned Intervention Coach both e-mail and call participants when an assessment is due and conduct e-mail or phone reminders, 2, 4, 7, 11, and 14 days after an assessment is due. If a participant refuses to complete the full online assessment, they are given the option of completing a 10-item assessment (for $5) that assesses key constructs over the phone or online. Using these procedures since the start of the study, we have been able to obtain full assessments at 93% of time points occurring during the intervention. Specifically, of eligible and enrolled participants, 100% completed the pretest, 91% completed the mid-treatment, 91% completed the posttest, 87% completed the 4-month follow-up, and 85% completed the 6-month follow-up. 
Collection of data on completion of online activities. Our Learning Management System (LMS) automatically tracks which activities participants completed and the time they took to complete those activities.

q8.value: 742 couples will be collected and randomized into three groups: 2 active conditions and a waitlist control group.

q9.value: The sample size was determined a priori in order to be sufficiently powered (.80) to detect a small between groups effect size controlling for initial level of the DV. Using the Optimal Design program (Raudenbush et al., 2011) with an alpha of .05, an intraclass correlation between partners of 0.65 (as demonstrated by Doss et al., 2016), power of .80, and a sample size of 705 couples, and controlling for pre-intervention levels of the DV, the study will be sufficiently powered (0.80) to detect an intervention effect on physical and mental health that is small in magnitude (Cohen’s d = 0.20) for the sample.

q10.value: Data collection will conclude when 742 couples have been randomized for the full sample.

question.value: Couples are randomized as a unit to two active treatment conditions (ePREP or OurRelationship) or the waitlist control.

Demographics. We collect information on gender, race/ethnicity, age, income, highest degree of education, employment, and relationship status.  
	Relationship Functioning.
Trust and Intimacy. In order to capture an increase in intimacy, we will collect the ACF mandated emotional support measure of trust and intimacy. A seven-item version of this measure was used in the Supporting Healthy Marriage project and reported alphas of 0.86 for men and 0.89 for women (Lowenstein et al., 2014). Here, the five item measure asks participants to rate statements from Strongly Agree (1) to Strongly Disagree (4). Scores will be reverse coded such that high scores indicate greater trust and intimacy. In a sample of 1327 individuals who have taken our screening survey, alpha was .83. 
Relationship Conflict. In order to capture a decrease of stress in the relationship, we will collect the ACF mandated negative communication measure of communication conflict. When this measure was used in the Supporting Healthy Marriage project, they reported alphas of 0.89 for men and women (Lowenstein et al., 2014). This seven item measure asks participants to rate statements from Never (1) to Often (4). Higher scores indicate greater communication conflict. In a sample of 1331 individuals who have taken our screening survey, alpha was .91.  
Psychological Health. 
	Psychological Distress. Measured by the Kessler Psychological Distress 6-item scale (K6), participants are classified as having severe psychological distress if they score 13 or greater. The K6 has strong reliability (alpha = .87) and a two factor model separating anxiety and depression fits better than a unidimensional factor (Bessaha, 2015). A sample item is, “In the last 30 days, how often have you felt nervous?” In a sample of 1310 individuals who have taken our screening survey, alpha was .89. 
Perceived Stress. The Perceived Stress Scale (Cohen & Williamson, 1988) is a 4-item measure tapping general feelings of being overwhelmed and out of control in ones’ life. Alpha reliability was 0.80 in our previous online studies. A sample item is, “In the last 30 days, how often have you felt that you were unable to control the important things in your life?” In a sample of 1317 individuals who have taken our screening survey, alpha was .74
	Alcohol Use. The 7-item PROMIS Alcohol Use measure, developed through the NIH Common Fund effort, will be used to assess problematic alcohol use in the past month (Pilkonis et al., 2013). In IRT analyses, it has an alpha > .90 for T-scores of alcohol use between 49 and 75. A sample item is, “In the last 30 days, how often have you felt that you were unable to control the important things in your life?” In a sample of 701 individuals who have taken our screening survey, alpha was .93. 
	Anger. The 5-item Anger-Short Form from the NIH PROMIS measure bank will be used to assess anger. In IRT analyses, it has an alpha > 0.90 for T-scores of anger between 40 and 82 (Pilkonis et al., 2011). A sample item is, “In the last 30 days, I was irritated more than other people.” In a sample of 1314 individuals who have taken our screening survey, alpha was .93
	Physical Health. 
Perceived Health. The 5-item General Health Perceptions subscale of the SF-36 will be used; it assesses overall physical (not mental) health (Ware & Sherbourne, 1992). Across multiple large-scale studies, M alpha = .81. A sample item is, “I am as healthy as anyone I know.” In a sample of 2633 individuals who have taken our screening survey, alpha was .81. 
	Self-reported Sleep. Sleep will be assessed for the full sample using the Insomnia Severity Index (ISI), a 5-item self-report measure. The ISI has acceptable internal consistency (alpha = 0.74), the internal reliability remained stable over the course of treatment, and was shown to be concurrently valid with clinicians’ evaluation of insomnia severity (Bastien, Vallières, & Morin, 2001). A sample item is, “how satisfied are you with your current sleep pattern?” In a sample of 1305 individuals who have taken our screening survey, alpha was .88. 
	Exercise. A one-item measure of exercise was adapted from the CDC BRFSS 2016 Questionnaire. Participants are asked to rate “During the last month, other than you regular job, did you participate in any physical activities or exercises such as running, working out, playing sports, gardening, or walking for exercise?” on a scale from 1- Not at all to 6- More than four times per week. The measure adequately captures sufficient physical activity and changes in physical activity over time (Dwyer-Lindgren et al., 2013).
only sum scores will be used.

q14.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study utilizes a three group design: two active interventions and a waitlist control groups. All participants are assessed at pre-treatment prior to randomization, one month after randomization (about 1/2 way through the active interventions), two months after randomization (at post test for intervention couples), four months after randomization (2 months after post for intervention couples), and 6 months after randomization (4 months after post for intervention couples).

q17.value: participants are randomized evenly into three groups at the couple level.

question.value:
Due to the nested nature of the data, I will utilize a three level hierarchical linear model nesting time at level one within individuals at level two within couples at level three. At level one, I will control for one time varying covariant indicating if the couple was together or separated at the time of the assessment. At level two, I will enter gender grand centered on the intercept and slopes in level one to account for extraneous variability as well as pre-treatment levels of the DV. At level three, I will enter a variable indicating if the couple dropped out of the program prematurely. 
I will model time at level one using a spline model such that the model will have a break point at post treatment. This will allow for the slope of change during the program to be different than during follow-up.
In order to test aim 4, I will use latent growth curves within a structural equation modeling framework. This allows for simultaneous modeling of multiple variables over time while accounting for the nested structure of the data.

q20.value: Gender will be grand mean centered, pre-treatment levels will be grand mean centered, and the drop-out indicator will be grand mean centered in order to obtain the average results rather than the results for the zero group.

q22.value: I will use two-tailed tests and p-values of less than .05 to indicate statistical significance.

q23.value: Data will be excluded when running analyses when there is not enough information to complete the model. Individuals must report on at least 3 time points in order to be included. Any major protocol deviations (such as cross contamination between active conditions) will be excluded from analysis.

q24.value: For Aims 1-3 data was imputed using a multi-level imputation program, Blimp, accounting for auxilary variables that were associated with the value of the DV or missingness including demographics and program non-completion.

registration_responses.q1: EFFECTS OF OURRELATIONSHIP AND EPREP ON INDIVIDUAL MENTAL AND PHYSICAL HEALTH FOR LOW INCOME COUPLES
registration_responses.q3:
1. Do online self-help relationship programs improve individual mental and physical health over the course of the program (2 months)?
2. Do online self-help relationship programs maintain improvements in individual mental health and improve individual physical health over short-term follow up (4 months)? 
3. Do initial levels of individual health moderate changes in individual mental health over the program and short term follow up as well as moderate changes in individual physical health over short term follow up? 
4. Are changes in individual physical health mediated through increases in intimacy, decreases in communication conflict, or decreases in psychological distress?
registration_responses.q4:
1. Individual mental health will improve over the course of the program. Individual physical health will not change over the course of the program. 
2. Individual metal health will maintain improvements seen during the program over short term follow up. Individual physical health will improve over short term follow up. 
3. Initial levels of individual health will moderate change in individual mental health over the program and in individual physical health over short term follow up. 
4. Decreases in relationship conflict and increases in relationship intimacy will mediate changes in individual physical health over the program.
registration_responses.q5: Registration following analysis of the data
registration_responses.q6: Data is collected as a part of an online program within the program software and through Qualtrics. All data is stored on Qualtrics servers and has been checked for completeness but not for content.
registration_responses.q8: 742 couples will be collected and randomized into three groups: 2 active conditions and a waitlist control group.
registration_responses.q9: The sample size was determined a priori in order to be sufficiently powered (.80) to detect a small between groups effect size controlling for initial level of the DV. Using the Optimal Design program (Raudenbush et al., 2011) with an alpha of .05, an intraclass correlation between partners of 0.65 (as demonstrated by Doss et al., 2016), power of .80, and a sample size of 705 couples, and controlling for pre-intervention levels of the DV, the study will be sufficiently powered (0.80) to detect an intervention effect on physical and mental health that is small in magnitude (Cohen’s d = 0.20) for the sample.
registration_responses.q10: Data collection will conclude when 742 couples have been randomized for the full sample.
registration_responses.q14: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q15: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q17: participants are randomized evenly into three groups at the couple level.
registration_responses.q20: Gender will be grand mean centered, pre-treatment levels will be grand mean centered, and the drop-out indicator will be grand mean centered in order to obtain the average results rather than the results for the zero group.
registration_responses.q22: I will use two-tailed tests and p-values of less than .05 to indicate statistical significance.
registration_responses.q23: Data will be excluded when running analyses when there is not enough information to complete the model. Individuals must report on at least 3 time points in order to be included. Any major protocol deviations (such as cross contamination between active conditions) will be excluded from analysis.
registration_responses.q24: For Aims 1-3 data was imputed using a multi-level imputation program, Blimp, accounting for auxilary variables that were associated with the value of the DV or missingness including demographics and program non-completion.
registration_responses.q7.question:
Data Collection Procedures. Participants enter all data online via Qualtrics. If a participant does not complete an assessment, we ask them to complete a brief, 10-question assessment (over the phone or online) for a $5 payment. Implementation data is collected by the intervention coaches and the Participant Coordinator.
Collection of participants’ responses to surveys. Participants are required to complete both the intake for eligibility screening purposes and pre-test questions online before enrolling in services.  Completion is tracked by the Participant Coordinator, who daily monitors completion of both surveys as a prerequisite to enrollment; therefore, there will be no missing data on these measures. 
Collection of the required measures is carefully monitored by project staff to ensure completion. The Participant Coordinator, the work-study student working with him/her, or the assigned Intervention Coach both e-mail and call participants when an assessment is due and conduct e-mail or phone reminders, 2, 4, 7, 11, and 14 days after an assessment is due. If a participant refuses to complete the full online assessment, they are given the option of completing a 10-item assessment (for $5) that assesses key constructs over the phone or online. Using these procedures since the start of the study, we have been able to obtain full assessments at 93% of time points occurring during the intervention. Specifically, of eligible and enrolled participants, 100% completed the pretest, 91% completed the mid-treatment, 91% completed the posttest, 87% completed the 4-month follow-up, and 85% completed the 6-month follow-up. 
Collection of data on completion of online activities. Our Learning Management System (LMS) automatically tracks which activities participants completed and the time they took to complete those activities.
registration_responses.q11.question: Couples are randomized as a unit to two active treatment conditions (ePREP or OurRelationship) or the waitlist control.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Demographics. We collect information on gender, race/ethnicity, age, income, highest degree of education, employment, and relationship status.  
	Relationship Functioning.
Trust and Intimacy. In order to capture an increase in intimacy, we will collect the ACF mandated emotional support measure of trust and intimacy. A seven-item version of this measure was used in the Supporting Healthy Marriage project and reported alphas of 0.86 for men and 0.89 for women (Lowenstein et al., 2014). Here, the five item measure asks participants to rate statements from Strongly Agree (1) to Strongly Disagree (4). Scores will be reverse coded such that high scores indicate greater trust and intimacy. In a sample of 1327 individuals who have taken our screening survey, alpha was .83. 
Relationship Conflict. In order to capture a decrease of stress in the relationship, we will collect the ACF mandated negative communication measure of communication conflict. When this measure was used in the Supporting Healthy Marriage project, they reported alphas of 0.89 for men and women (Lowenstein et al., 2014). This seven item measure asks participants to rate statements from Never (1) to Often (4). Higher scores indicate greater communication conflict. In a sample of 1331 individuals who have taken our screening survey, alpha was .91.  
Psychological Health. 
	Psychological Distress. Measured by the Kessler Psychological Distress 6-item scale (K6), participants are classified as having severe psychological distress if they score 13 or greater. The K6 has strong reliability (alpha = .87) and a two factor model separating anxiety and depression fits better than a unidimensional factor (Bessaha, 2015). A sample item is, “In the last 30 days, how often have you felt nervous?” In a sample of 1310 individuals who have taken our screening survey, alpha was .89. 
Perceived Stress. The Perceived Stress Scale (Cohen & Williamson, 1988) is a 4-item measure tapping general feelings of being overwhelmed and out of control in ones’ life. Alpha reliability was 0.80 in our previous online studies. A sample item is, “In the last 30 days, how often have you felt that you were unable to control the important things in your life?” In a sample of 1317 individuals who have taken our screening survey, alpha was .74
	Alcohol Use. The 7-item PROMIS Alcohol Use measure, developed through the NIH Common Fund effort, will be used to assess problematic alcohol use in the past month (Pilkonis et al., 2013). In IRT analyses, it has an alpha > .90 for T-scores of alcohol use between 49 and 75. A sample item is, “In the last 30 days, how often have you felt that you were unable to control the important things in your life?” In a sample of 701 individuals who have taken our screening survey, alpha was .93. 
	Anger. The 5-item Anger-Short Form from the NIH PROMIS measure bank will be used to assess anger. In IRT analyses, it has an alpha > 0.90 for T-scores of anger between 40 and 82 (Pilkonis et al., 2011). A sample item is, “In the last 30 days, I was irritated more than other people.” In a sample of 1314 individuals who have taken our screening survey, alpha was .93
	Physical Health. 
Perceived Health. The 5-item General Health Perceptions subscale of the SF-36 will be used; it assesses overall physical (not mental) health (Ware & Sherbourne, 1992). Across multiple large-scale studies, M alpha = .81. A sample item is, “I am as healthy as anyone I know.” In a sample of 2633 individuals who have taken our screening survey, alpha was .81. 
	Self-reported Sleep. Sleep will be assessed for the full sample using the Insomnia Severity Index (ISI), a 5-item self-report measure. The ISI has acceptable internal consistency (alpha = 0.74), the internal reliability remained stable over the course of treatment, and was shown to be concurrently valid with clinicians’ evaluation of insomnia severity (Bastien, Vallières, & Morin, 2001). A sample item is, “how satisfied are you with your current sleep pattern?” In a sample of 1305 individuals who have taken our screening survey, alpha was .88. 
	Exercise. A one-item measure of exercise was adapted from the CDC BRFSS 2016 Questionnaire. Participants are asked to rate “During the last month, other than you regular job, did you participate in any physical activities or exercises such as running, working out, playing sports, gardening, or walking for exercise?” on a scale from 1- Not at all to 6- More than four times per week. The measure adequately captures sufficient physical activity and changes in physical activity over time (Dwyer-Lindgren et al., 2013).
registration_responses.q13.question: only sum scores will be used.
registration_responses.q16.question: This study utilizes a three group design: two active interventions and a waitlist control groups. All participants are assessed at pre-treatment prior to randomization, one month after randomization (about 1/2 way through the active interventions), two months after randomization (at post test for intervention couples), four months after randomization (2 months after post for intervention couples), and 6 months after randomization (4 months after post for intervention couples).
registration_responses.q19.question:
Due to the nested nature of the data, I will utilize a three level hierarchical linear model nesting time at level one within individuals at level two within couples at level three. At level one, I will control for one time varying covariant indicating if the couple was together or separated at the time of the assessment. At level two, I will enter gender grand centered on the intercept and slopes in level one to account for extraneous variability as well as pre-treatment levels of the DV. At level three, I will enter a variable indicating if the couple dropped out of the program prematurely. 
I will model time at level one using a spline model such that the model will have a break point at post treatment. This will allow for the slope of change during the program to be different than during follow-up.
In order to test aim 4, I will use latent growth curves within a structural equation modeling framework. This allows for simultaneous modeling of multiple variables over time while accounting for the nested structure of the data.

attributes.title: Political bullshit receptivity
attributes.description: Cross-cultural (U.S., Netherlands and Serbia) investigation of political bullshit receptivity

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: Table of correlations for all measures. Correlations with political bullshit receptivity when the endorsement of factual statements is controlled for.

sample.value: Given that the Bayesian inference is used (see data analysis), the evidence can be monitored as the data is collected. This means that the stopping rule is not determined using power analysis, but by evidence achieved or depleted resources (Rouder, 2014; Wagenmakers et al., 2018). Additionally, given that our research question is answered by a pattern of results rather than a single test, our sample size is determined by available resources. Therefore, we plan at least 150 participants in each study-a sample size also indicated by Bayes factor > 3 in favor of a one-sided alternative for r = .2 (using stretched beta prior width of 1). If analyses give inconclusive results, we will increase our sample size, up to 220 participants per study (for a similar approach, see Matzke et al., 2015).

analyses.value: Given the complexity of the research question, we summarize general approach in data analysis. First, the one-factor structure of the political bullshit receptivity scale is to be tested using Structural Equation Modelling (the same is expected for slogans and bullshit political program). The relationship between all continuous variables will be tested using Pearson correlations in the Bayesian framework. Bayesian meta-analysis of the most important correlations (ee the document "Hypotheses table") will be used to calculate the average size of the relationship. Whether political bullshit measures (political bullshit scale, slogans and bullshit political program) predict voting behavior (past and future election choice) will be investigated with Linear discriminant analysis (LDA), but only for clusters with more than 10% of the cases. If the assumptions for LDA are not met, multinomial logistic regression will be performed (Poulsen & French, 2008).

outliers.value: Before analyses, multivariate outliers on continuous dependent variables (Mahalanobis distance), speeders (completion under 180 seconds) and participants who fail the attention check will be excluded.

dependent.value: All measures are given in another file at OSF ("Materials for Political Bullshit").

conditions.value: Given that this is a correlational study, all participants will fill out the same scales. An exception is a question about voting because the parties/candidates differ across three countries in which studies are conducted (the U.S., The Netherlands, Serbia). See the materials file for more details.

hypothesis.value: The main question is to operationalize political bullshit receptivity which we measure as an endorsement of political statements that are vague and meaningless (e.g. “It is of the utmost importance that political leaders believe in their country”). We expect it to correlate highly with other measures of political bullshit (slogan and bullshit program endorsements; convergent validity), to be related to ideological measures (political ideology, neoliberalism, populism) and to pseudo-profound bullshit receptivity. We also test how it predicts voting behavior.

attributes.title: Bullshit receptivity
attributes.description: Intelligence as a factor in pseudo-profound bullshit receptivity.

q1.value: Cognitive Abilities' Effects on the Reception of Pseudo-Profound Bullshit

q2.value: Mia Burkhardt, Madison Beadle, Tanisha Fleming

q3.value: Though there is significant evidence that some people have higher levels of receptivity towards pseudo-profound bullshit, there is not much evidence that connects the cognitive ability to the degree of receptiveness. We are replicating a previous study conducted by Gordon Pennycook and colleagues, in which they measure participant's abilities to indicate levels of profundity after reading a statement, while also giving cognitive and demographic questions. In our study, we will hone in on the cognitive ability of participants over the age of 18, and measure intelligence levels along with bullshit receptivity to determine whether there is an association between the two.

q4.value:
1. (a) Higher levels of cognitive ability negatively influence receptivity to pseudo-profound bullshit. (b) positively influence an individual’s ability to distinguish between factual and falsified information. 

This is directional, as we are hypothesizing that higher levels of cognitive ability is related to lower levels of pseudo-profound bullshit receptivity.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The design and measurements will be replicated as it was in the Pennycook 2015 study. Specifics on the measurements and design are detailed in the attached files. The study will be an observational study that will include intellectual and cognitive tests.

We will use a Pearson product-moment correlation as used in the Pennycook 2015 study to compare both factors within our subject group to analyze our results.

attributes.title: Pseudo-profound Bullshit
attributes.description: What makes someone more likely to fall for psuedo-profound bullshit? This replication study seeks to explore the relationship between an individuals critical thinking skills and their receptivity of pseudo-profound bullshit, as is measured by the scale presented in the Pennycook et al. 2015 study. The tasks that will be completed measure various aspects of an individual's cognitive reasoning skills, including measures of both verbal and analytical reasoning.

q1.value: Bullshit Receptivity in College Students: a Replication of Pennycook et al. (2015)

q2.value: Genevieve Breckoff, Kaitlyn Knutsen, Devin Reinoso, Amanda Smith, lauren estrada

q3.value: As the findings of Pennycook et al. (2015) and the subsequent studies using their metric are fairly recent, we hope to conduct the study on college undergraduates. We will measure their analytical capabilities along with administering the bullshit receptivity scale created by Pennycook, et al.

q4.value: As this is a replication study, we share our hypotheses with the article from which we draw our inspiration. That is, that those who score highly on the measure of pseudo-profound bullshit receptivity should score lowly on the measure of analytical reasoning.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
For study 1, it is a within subjects design rating 10 sentences presented randomly on a scale with 5 response anchors (Bullshit Receptivity Scale). Participants also complete multiple cognitive tests to assess cognitive ability and differences (Cognitive Reflection Test, Heuristics and Biases, Verbal Intelligence, Numeracy, Ontological Confusions, Religious Belief).
The tests will be administered in the following order: Heuristics and Biases Battery, Wordsum, , Numeracy, CRT1, CRT2, Ontological Confusions, Bullshit Receptivity Scale, Religiosity Inventory.  The Heuristics and Biases battery is composed of several tests. The Wordsum test measures an individual's verbal reasoning skills. The Numeracy measures an individual's analytical reasoning skills, testing them on a series of mathematical problems. The Numeracy test is followed by two Cognitive Reasoning Tests, one shorter and one expanded, which also measure analytical reasoning skills through a series of mathematics questions. Following the Cognitive Reasoning Tasks, participants will be administered the Ontological Confusions Test, in which the participants will be asked to distinguish between sentences with and without a literal meaning. Next, participants will be administered the Bullshit Receptivity Scale, in which the participants will be asked to distinguish between sentences with and without a discernible meaning. Finally, participants will complete a religiosity inventory, in which they will be asked to rate the frequency of their participation in religious activities, their importance, and the strength of those beliefs.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will conduct our study on a sample of 280 college undergraduates. All participants must be native English speakers. We will recruit our participants by providing the incentive of extra credit in one of their classes. Our study will follow a two semester timeline.

q13.value: The sample size of our study will be 280 undergraduates, keeping with the original Pennycook et al. (2015) study of the same sample size.

q14.value: In the original study, the researchers were able to find significant results at that sample size.

question.value: We manipulated the type of statement that the participant was reading and had to rate. The different statements were Deepak Chopra’s tweets, statements from Seb Pearce, statements that convey meaning but are mundane, and motivational quotations.
The measured variables were profundity ratings of each of the statements. The ratings were on a scale from 1-5 (1 being not profound at all to 5 being very profound).
We will use Pearson product-moment correlations to analyze our results.

q21.value: We will use the criteria of p<.05 for determining significance of Pearson product-moment correlations.

q22.value: We will exclude data from participants who fail to answer a majority of the questions.

q25.value:
We were unable to gain access to the Toplak 2011 Heuristics and Biases battery, however, the citation for that battery is as follows:
Toplak, M. V., West, R. F., & Stanovich, K. E. (2011). The Cognitive Reflection Test as a predictor of performance on heuristics-and-biases tasks. Memory & Cognition, 39, 1275–1289.

Next, participants will be administered the Bullshit Receptivity Scale, in which the participants will be asked to distinguish between sentences with and without a discernible meaning. Finally, participants will complete a religiosity inventory, in which they will be asked to rate the frequency of their participation in religious activities, their importance, and the strength of those beliefs.
registration_responses.q12.question: We will conduct our study on a sample of 280 college undergraduates. All participants must be native English speakers. We will recruit our participants by providing the incentive of extra credit in one of their classes. Our study will follow a two semester timeline.
registration_responses.q16.question: We manipulated the type of statement that the participant was reading and had to rate. The different statements were Deepak Chopra’s tweets, statements from Seb Pearce, statements that convey meaning but are mundane, and motivational quotations.
registration_responses.q17.question: The measured variables were profundity ratings of each of the statements. The ratings were on a scale from 1-5 (1 being not profound at all to 5 being very profound).
registration_responses.q19.question: We will use Pearson product-moment correlations to analyze our results.

attributes.title: People we are stuck with during the quarantine - are they a burden or support? Data from COVIDiSTRESS
attributes.description: Here, we intend to analyze data from COVIDiSTRESS global survey (pre-registration can be found under the link: https://osf.io/2ftma/), and investigate the role of the number of adults the respondents are staying with while in relative isolation, the number of children, marital status, age, culture, and gender on levels of stress.

q1.value: Marta Kowal, Oli Ahmed, Gözde Ikizer, Anna Studzinska, Kristina Eichel, Arooj Najmussaqib, Karolina Koszałkowska

q2.value:
All of our hypotheses address the current situation (i.e. coronavirus pandemic).
H1: Individuals staying alone and those who are subjected to overcrowding while in isolation experience highest levels of perceived stress.
H2: Married and cohabiting persons experience lower levels of stress compared with persons that are single.
H3: Individuals with children would report increased stress during the COVID-19 pandemic compared to people living alone or with adults. Levels of perceived stress would increase as the number of children at home increases. 
H4: Younger people experience more stress than older people.
H5: Collectivistic cultures experience less stress than individualistic cultures.
H6: Men experience higher levels of stress compared with women.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
According to the pre-registration of COVIDiSTRESS global survey (which can be found under the link: https://osf.io/s32gy):

The COVIDiSTRESS global survey is an international collaborative undertaking for data gathering on people’s experiences, behavior and attitudes during the COVID-19 pandemic. In particular, the survey focuses on psychological stress, compliance with behavioral guidelines to slow the spread of Coronavirus, and trust in governmental institutions and their preventive measures, but multiple further items and scales are included for descriptive statistics, further analysis and comparative mapping between participating countries.

To gather comparable data swiftly from across the globe, the collaboration and survey was constructed as an urgent collaborative process in late March 2020.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value:
The data collection has began on March 30, 2020.
Data will be made available for public use on the Open Science Framework. Data extraction is scheduled for cumulative “dumps” every Monday until May 30, 2020.
The first data extraction will take place April 06, 2020, and the current pre-registration is being submitted before the first data extraction (April 05, 2020).

question.value: Data is being collected by committed researchers in 43+ countries. Data is collected through online means, mainly based on social snowballing, viral spread and help from interested partners.

q11.value: We intend to analyze the data from countries, where minimum of 300 responses have been collected.

question.value:
- Perceived Stress. This variable will be assessed by the Perceived Stress Scale, 10-item version (Cohen et al., 1983) and their respective language adaptations (if available), or forward-back translations, using WHO recommendations.  

- Demographic variables: age, gender, marital status, a number of dependents (i.e. children)

- Variables related to life during the pandemic: number of adults staying together in isolation
Based on the Hofstede insights, we will assign the Individualistic value for each, analyzed country (i.e. the country that has a minimum of 300 completed responses).
We will conduct linear regression analysis to test, whether IVs are significant predictors of stress levels.
